tutorial.title: Adding Loops to Functions
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to add loops to functions to speed up tedious tasks.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's use functions to call loops and influence their output.

This app for example uses a loop inside a function to guide you during a workout. Press the button to call the function.

lessons.title: Simple loop
lessons.interactiveContent:
We learned loops repeat the instructions inside their braces. Make this code display numbers from 0 to 4.

Make sure to pick 0, followed by 5.

lessons.title: No parameter
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we have to repeat the same instructions more than once, we can add a loop inside a function.

Make sure to pick for (let i = 1; i <= 3; i++) followed by { and then console.log("And a " + i);, }.

lessons.title: Loops in functions
lessons.interactiveContent: We can use parameters to get different results from the same loop. Check out the output for this function called with different parameters.

lessons.title: Control what it shows
lessons.interactiveContent:
To change what a loop displays, we use parameters to do things like adding a string right after the counter variable.

Make sure to pick message.

lessons.title: Tedious tasks are easier
lessons.interactiveContent: Adding loops to functions makes tedious tasks fast and flexible. Here, we display 20 different messages with two function calls.

lessons.title: Multiplier parameter
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use parameters to change operations, like multiplication. This one function is enough to create different multiplication tables.

Make sure to pick multiplier.

lessons.title: Question: Simple loop
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we know this function always displays the same sequence of numbers?

Because the output isn't updated by any parametersIt doesn't, it'll have different output each time

Because the output isn't updated by any parameters.

lessons.title: Question: No parameter
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

The numbers 1 to 3The numbers 1 to 3 followed by a value we passed to the function

The numbers 1 to 3.

lessons.title: Question: Loops in functions
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens when we use a parameter like in the function below?

Depending on the value passed to it, the function displays a different message The function always displays the same message, no matter the value passed to it

Depending on the value passed to it, the function displays a different message .

lessons.title: Question: Control what it shows
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

Four lines in the consoleOne line in the console

Four lines in the console.

lessons.title: Question: Tedious tasks are easier
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

Eight lines in the consoleFour lines in the console

Eight lines in the console.

lessons.title: Question: Multiplier parameter
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

The numbers 10 to 12The numbers 0 to 2

The numbers 10 to 12.

lessons.title: Example: Simple loop
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the numbers 0 to 9.

Make sure to pick displayNumbers followed by ( and then ), ;.

lessons.title: Example: No parameter
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the correct braces and parentheses.

Make sure to pick { followed by ( and then ), {, }, }.

lessons.title: Example: Loops in functions
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display Check Mirrors as the last message.

Make sure to pick "Fasten seat belt", followed by "Check Mirrors".

lessons.title: Example: Control what it shows
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the message parameter after each number.

Make sure to pick i, followed by +, and finally message.

lessons.title: Example: Tedious tasks are easier
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the page parameter before each number.

Make sure to pick page, followed by +, and finally i.

lessons.title: Example: Multiplier parameter
lessons.interactiveContent:
Multiply the counter variable by coding the right parameter.

Make sure to pick *, followed by multiplier.

chapters.title: How to use loops with functions

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's learn the basics of using and controlling loops inside functions.

See this example that displays a custom number of workout repetitions? It uses a parameter to tell the loop how many times to run.

lessons.title: Code block
lessons.interactiveContent:
Since for loops are blocks of code, we add them to functions the same way we add if statements, between braces and indented.

Make sure to pick { followed by { and then }, }.

lessons.title: Pass value
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can pass values as parameters to control how many times a loop gets executed. Display Beetlejuice three times by passing a number.

Make sure to pick 3.

lessons.title: End point
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use parameters to mark the endpoint of a loop. Code the times parameter inside the loop condition.

Make sure to type times.

lessons.title: Beginning
lessons.interactiveContent:
To control where a loop starts, we use a parameter to set the counter variable's value. This code displays the days left in a month.

Make sure to pick let followed by i and then =, day.

lessons.title: Fine-tune
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use parameters to set both the start and end values. This code only displays numbers in between the values we passed to the function.

Make sure to pick start, followed by end.

lessons.title: Question: Code block
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we add a loop inside a function?

By indenting the entire loop by one space Only the instructions inside the loop have to be indented by one space

By indenting the entire loop by one space .

lessons.title: Question: Pass value
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

The * sign on five different linesThe * sign on one line

The * sign on five different lines.

lessons.title: Question: End point
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

The $ sign on three different linesThe word "sign" on three different lines

The $ sign on three different lines.

lessons.title: Question: Beginning
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we control a loop's starting point?

By using a parameter to set the counter variableWe can't, we have to write new loops

By using a parameter to set the counter variable.

lessons.title: Question: Fine-tune
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

1998, 1999, and 2000 on different linesThe numbers 0 to 2000 on different lines

1998, 1999, and 2000 on different lines.

lessons.title: Example: Code block
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the correct snippets to make the loop work.

Make sure to pick i < 3.

lessons.title: Example: Pass value
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the correct snippets.

Make sure to pick let i = 0;, followed by i < times;, and finally i++.

lessons.title: Example: End point
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the parameters in their correct positions.

Make sure to pick times, followed by sign.

lessons.title: Example: Beginning
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the function's parameter to set the counter variable.

Make sure to pick start followed by let and then i, =, start.

lessons.title: Example: Fine-tune
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the parameters by coding start, end.

Make sure to type start, end.
